text: the British people have spoken and the
answer is we're out it's taken more than
18 months to get here and it hasn't been
easy but the brexit deal is now agreed
the negotiators have done their bit
ministers are finally on board with the
details of how we leave the EU and a
strategy for how the future looks now
Breck's it's about to hit one of its
biggest moments yet when Westminster 650
MPs have to decide whether to give it
their blessing but they can't agree at
all the opposition parties are all
against it and even dozens of Tereza
Mays own MPs have said they'll be voting
against it and everyone has different
reasons I don't see how you can support
it from a Democratic point of view this
is not brexit this is a failure of
government policy it needs to be
rejected Parliament is gridlocked that's
just the simple honest truth of it the
Prime Minister's been out trying to sell
her deal and there's been huge efforts
to try to win round unhappy
conservatives MPs have days to debate
all the ins and outs of it here in the
Commons chamber where we're not usually
allowed to film so when it's time for a
vote a bell will ring across Parliament
that lets MPs know that they have eight
minutes to get here to make their choice
they can decide to go through that
corridor to say yes all that one to say
no MPs physically have to walk through
these division lobbies where their names
are recorded and their numbers are added
up most will have made up their minds
long before they arrive here but on an
issue as big as this some will be
weighing up until the last minute the
instructions from their parties the
views of their constituents and their
own beliefs
if a majority of MPs agree to back the
brexit deal then it will be full steam
ahead for leaving the EU at the end of
March but that's looking so unlikely and
if Parliament gives the thumbs down then
really anything could happen it would be
such a major issue for a Prime Minister
to lose a vote on that labour could try
to force an election and Tory MPs could
decide that Theresa May can't stay on as
the one in charge of their party she
could try to go back to Brussels for
more talks even though they've said
that's not an option but even then it's
not clear how a new deal would satisfy
enough MPs she could ask for more time
to negotiate to avoid having to leave
the EU with no proper deal but then
supporters of another referendum think
that would give them a chance to hold
another public vote there's never been a
situation like this before so it's all
so uncertain and it's all now up to each
individual MP to decide which path to go
down
